column1: Kamyshin (Russian: Камы́шин) is a city in Volgograd Oblast
column3: located on the right bank of the Volgograd Reservoir of the Volga River
column4: in the estuary of the Kamyshinka River. Population: 119

column1: It was founded in 1667 on the left bank of the Kamyshinka River. In 1710
column2: all of its inhabitants were relocated to the fortress of Dmitriyevsk (Дмитриевск) on the opposite bank of the river. In 1780
column3: the name was changed to Kamyshin and it was granted town status. In the 19th century
column4: Kamyshin turned into a merchant city with sawmills and windmills. It was formerly famous for its watermelon trade.

column1: === Portage between the Volga and Don Rivers ===

column2: the Volga is quite close—17 kilometers (11 mi)—to the upper reaches of the Ilovlya River

column5: and the Ilovlya is only a little more than 4 kilometers (2.5 mi). In this place in ancient times there existed a portage ("volok") many times used by the troops invading the land of the Khazars
column6: and moving from the Don basin to the Volga. In the 16th century
column7: the Turkish Sultan Selim II attempted to build a canal here. A similar effort was later made by Peter the Great who built the fort
column9: to protect workmen during the (unfinished) construction of the canal.

column1: Within the framework of administrative divisions
column2: Kamyshin serves as the administrative center of Kamyshinsky District
column3: even though it is not a part of it. As an administrative division
column4: it is incorporated separately as the city of oblast significance of Kamyshin—an administrative unit with the status equal to that of the districts. As a municipal division
column5: the city of oblast significance of Kamyshin is incorporated as Kamyshin Urban Okrug.
